objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to present Assay2Mol, a large language model-based workflow that leverages existing biochemical screening assays for early-stage drug discovery by generating candidate molecules using in-context learning.
objective.evidence: We present Assay2Mol, a large language model-based workflow that can capitalize on the vast existing biochemical screening assays for early-stage drug discovery.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the challenge of utilizing unstructured text in BioAssay records for drug discovery, which has been largely untapped due to its format.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Unstructured text that describes the biological mechanisms through which these targets operate, experimental screening protocols, and other attributes of assays offer rich information for new drug discovery campaigns but has been untapped because of that unstructured format.

answer: Assay2Mol does not require protein structures or sequences, unlike traditional structure-based drug discovery methods.
Assay2Mol generates molecules that are chemically plausible and synthetically accessible by relying on LLMs pretrained on chemical data.
The workflow retrieves relevant PubChem BioAssay data and uses in-context learning to generate new candidate molecules.
evidence: Unlike structure-based drug discovery (SBDD) methods, Assay2Mol does not require protein structures or even sequences.
Because Assay2Mol relies on LLMs that are pretrained on chemical data for its molecule generation, the output molecules can be more like 'retrieval' rather than de novo 'generation'.
We introduce Assay2Mol, an LLM-based drug design workflow that retrieves relevant PubChem BioAssay data for a given query and then learns to generate new candidate molecules from this assay context.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- Kim et al. (2024) PubChem now contains 1.77 million assay records (BioAssay records) comprising ∼300 million bioactivity outcomes across ∼250,000 protein targets and 1,000s of cell lines. (Experimental baselines)
- Mendez et al. (2018) ChEMBL: towards direct deposition of bioassay data. (Experimental baselines)
inspirational_papers.evidence: Public screening data repositories like PubChem (Kim et al., 2024) and ChEMBL (Mendez et al., 2018) possess great value in this regard.

steps.step: Retrieve relevant BioAssays based on protein target descriptions.
steps.input: Protein target descriptions, phenotypic data, or other textual information.
steps.evidence: Given input such as protein target descriptions, phenotypic data, or other textual information, Assay2Mol retrieves relevant BioAssays.

steps.step: Summarize BioAssays and retrieve experimental tables.
steps.evidence: The BioAssay ID is then used to retrieve experimental tables.

steps.step: Generate candidate molecules using LLM with BioAssay context.
steps.input: Query protein description, BioAssay summaries, and data tables.
steps.evidence: Assay2Mol uses the LLM to generate molecules in batches of 10.

tools.name: OpenAI text embedding tool
tools.description: Used to obtain an embedding for BioAssay records.
tools.evidence: We use the OpenAI text embedding tool (Neelakantan et al., 2022) and obtain an embedding for BioAssay record i in json format.

tools.name: AutoDock Vina
tools.description: Used to score the binding complementarity of a molecule with a protein target.
tools.evidence: The average AutoDock Vina (Eberhardt et al., 2021) score for the five molecules without BioAssay context is -7.44.

benchmark_datasets.name: CrossDocked2020
benchmark_datasets.data_description: A dataset for structure-based drug design with docked protein binding complexes.
benchmark_datasets.usage: Used to assess how BioAssay context compares to protein structure context for generating candidate protein binders.
benchmark_datasets.evidence: CrossDocked2020 (CrossDocked for short) is a common dataset for SBDD (Francoeur et al., 2020) that allows us to assess how BioAssay context compares to protein structure context for generating candidate protein binders.

evaluation_metrics.name: Vina Dock
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the binding complementarity of a molecule with a protein target.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to score the generated molecules' interaction strength with protein targets.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: We use Vina Dock to score the binding complementarity of a molecule, or the strength of interaction, with a protein target.

evaluation_metrics.name: Qualitative Estimate of Drug-Likeness (QED)
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the drug-likeness of generated molecules.
evaluation_metrics.application: Computed with RDKit to evaluate the generated molecules.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: Qualitative Estimate of Drug-Likeness (QED) and Synthetic Accessibility (SA) are computed with RDKit (Landrum, 2016).

methods.name: Literature or Dataset Retrieval
methods.description: The system retrieves relevant BioAssays based on input descriptions.
methods.evidence: Given input such as protein target descriptions, phenotypic data, or other textual information, Assay2Mol retrieves relevant BioAssays.

methods.name: Knowledge Extraction and Structurization
methods.description: The system summarizes BioAssays and retrieves experimental tables.
methods.evidence: The BioAssay ID is then used to retrieve experimental tables.

methods.name: Hypothesis or Idea Generation
methods.description: The system generates candidate molecules using LLM with BioAssay context.
methods.evidence: Assay2Mol uses the LLM to generate molecules in batches of 10.

areas.name: Health Sciences
areas.description: The paper focuses on drug discovery using biochemical screening assays.
areas.evidence: We present Assay2Mol, a large language model-based workflow that can capitalize on the vast existing biochemical screening assays for early-stage drug discovery.

areas.name: Chemical Sciences
areas.description: The methodology involves generating chemically plausible molecules.
areas.evidence: Because Assay2Mol relies on LLMs that are pretrained on chemical data for its molecule generation, the output molecules can be more like 'retrieval' rather than de novo 'generation'.

performance_summary.summary: Assay2Mol consistently outperforms the best SBDD method, TargetDiff, in average docking scores.
performance_summary.evidence: All versions of Assay2Mol consistently outperform the best SBDD method, TargetDiff, in average docking scores (Table 1).

baselines.name: TargetDiff
baselines.description: A structure-based drug design method used for comparison.
baselines.evidence: We compare Assay2Mol against the following SBDD methods: CVAE (Ragoza et al., 2022), AR (Luo et al., 2022), Pocket2Mol (Peng et al., 2022), GraphBP (Liu et al., 2022), TamGen (Wu et al., 2024) and TargetDiff (Guan et al., 2023).

benchmark_datasets.name: CrossDocked2020
benchmark_datasets.data_description: A dataset for structure-based drug design with docked protein binding complexes.
benchmark_datasets.usage: Used to assess how BioAssay context compares to protein structure context for generating candidate protein binders.
benchmark_datasets.evidence: CrossDocked2020 (CrossDocked for short) is a common dataset for SBDD (Francoeur et al., 2020) that allows us to assess how BioAssay context compares to protein structure context for generating candidate protein binders.

evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the binding complementarity of a molecule with a protein target.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to score the generated molecules' interaction strength with protein targets.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: We use Vina Dock to score the binding complementarity of a molecule, or the strength of interaction, with a protein target.

evaluation_metrics.evidence: Qualitative Estimate of Drug-Likeness (QED) and Synthetic Accessibility (SA) are computed with RDKit (Landrum, 2016).

benchmark_dataset.usage: Used to assess how BioAssay context compares to protein structure context for generating candidate protein binders.

limitations.name: Relevance Assessment Imperfection
limitations.description: The LLM's assessment of BioAssay relevance is not always accurate, leading to potential misalignment in molecule design.
limitations.evidence: Having LLMs directly assess the relevance of the retrieved BioAssay text guards against many irrelevant matches but is imperfect (Table 4).

limitations.name: Conditional Query Processing
limitations.description: The current version cannot properly process conditional text queries, which limits its applicability in complex scenarios.
limitations.evidence: A related limitation is that the current version of Assay2Mol cannot properly process conditional text queries, such as molecules that inhibit proteins A, B, and C but not D and E.

future_directions.name: Enhance Retrieval Pipeline
future_directions.description: Develop a more robust retrieval pipeline to improve the selection of relevant BioAssays.
future_directions.evidence: Developing a more robust retrieval pipeline remains a priority for future work.

future_directions.name: Optimize LLM Prompts
future_directions.description: Evaluate the sensitivity of Assay2Mol to different LLM prompting strategies and optimize the prompts.
future_directions.evidence: Finally, we have not yet evaluated the sensitivity of Assay2Mol to different LLM prompting strategies or optimized the prompts.

resource_link.evidence: The code is available at https://github.com/gitter-lab/Assay2Mol under the MIT License.
